Award.AwardTitle: Scholars Award: An Empirical Study of the Making and Re-Making of Knowledge About Risk

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award is to support an empirical investigation of knowledge-making practices in an organization that has recently launched an ambitious research program intended to make building construction more resilient to severe weather by identifying sources of risk, develop mitigation strategies, and trigger widespread change. That organization is the Insurance Institute for Home and Business Safety, a nonprofit funded by property and casualty insurance companies, which opened a unique research center in rural South Carolina in 2010. The purpose of the center is to produce and communicate knowledge about how to mitigate damage from extreme weather events, such as hurricanes, wildfires, hailstorms, and wind-driven rain. The centerpiece of the center is an enormous wind tunnel large enough to test full-scale buildings. The study of this center that is being supported by this award has as its overarching goal to understand how knowledge about risk is made and remade as a way of getting at broader conceptions of risk. The primary outcome of this project is its contribution of a case study for a book manuscript; the book will mainly be of interest to social science audiences, particularly the multi-disciplinary community of scholars interested in risk. The PI will also produce at least one article for policy makers and risk managers, a perspective piece for a science policy forum, at least one article for a general interest audience. The results of this project will have implications for public policy, the insurance industry, and damage mitigation; this is particularly so given the prospects of climate change.

This project aims to advance theory and empirical knowledge about the work of experts who self-consciously set out to transform the conceptual frameworks and management practices through which society copes with a specific set of hazards. Understanding how knowledge about risk is made and remade is important for both intellectual and practical reasons. The empirical research will enable the PI to further develop theory about how dynamic change in knowledge about causation and control of risk shapes technological artifacts, systems, and infrastructures. The research will also shed light on the challenges of producing persuasive results and on the reception, uptake, and repackaging of mitigation knowledge.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Many vital systems--such as those undergirding the electric grid, public health surveillance, and cybersecurity--are vast infrastructures, built and maintained by a huge number of organizationally dispersed actors. This project was designed to shed light on the challenges of identifying the causes of risk in such systems and promoting promising risk mitigation strategies. The study explored how change in knowledge about the causes and control of risk takes place, examining how knowledge is made and remade during scientific work and during efforts to encourage new policies and practices. To investigate this process, the principal investigator conducted a case study of making knowledge about the risks of extreme weather events, such as hurricanes, wildfires, and hailstorms.

The case study centered on the Insurance Institute for Home and Business Safety (IBHS), a nonprofit funded by property and casualty insurance companies. In 2010, the IBHS opened a unique research center (RC). Its purpose? To produce and communicate knowledge about how to reduce damage from hurricanes, wildfires, hailstorms, and wind-driven rain. The centerpiece of this $40 million facility is an enormous wind tunnel large enough to test full-scale buildings. It can subject two-story houses and small commercial buildings to hurricane-force winds; bombard wooden houses with wind-driven embers like those produced by wildfires; and shoot ice balls with air guns to mimic hail. No similar facility exists. The RC seeks to identify cost-effective interventions, such as changes in construction practices, that can make buildings much less vulnerable to damage.

The goals of the RC extend beyond doing important research on buildings. The IBHS ultimately seeks to facilitate significant change in the wider world. It aims not merely to produce new knowledge but also to communicate it in ways that will, over time, transform how the risks of "natural" disasters are conceptualized and managed. Its leaders say they want "to do for homes and buildings what the crash test people did for cars." This worthwhile task is a daunting one given the scale of the construction industry. Making buildings more resilient entails changing what a huge number of decision makers think and do, including real-estate developers, contractors, suppliers of building components, home owners, realtors, state and local governments, and organizations that set engineering standards.

The case study examined the RC's efforts to make and communicate risk knowledge. It also investigated the uptake of this knowledge in construction and policymaking in the southeastern US, especially Alabama. The data the principal investigator collected enabled him to extend existing theory about how dynamic change in knowledge about causation and control of risk shapes technological artifacts, systems, and infrastructures. The study also illuminated the challenges of producing persuasive results, thus shedding light on the reception, uptake, and repackaging of mitigation knowledge. Finally, the research identified political challenges and questions of fairness and justice in risk mitigation.

The main product of the research will be a monograph presenting the empirical case study, its theoretical perspective, and its wider implications. The majority of the project was completed by fall of 2019, and the plan was to complete the monograph by July 31, 2020. However, like many other researchers, the principal investigator shifted his attention to urgent research in response to the COVID-19 pandemic in early 2020. The COVID research, supported by an NSF RAPID grant and later additional funding from a foundation, has dominated his research agenda for more than a year. This temporary shift in research priorities is drawing to a close, and the PI plans to reallocate his time to enable him complete the project in the near future. Following submission of the manuscript, he plans to ensure that the findings are shared with stakeholders through a science policy piece and via targeted blog posts and an article for a general audience. Regarding pedagogical material, project results have already been used in graduate teaching. An update to this Project Outcome Report will be provided upon completion of the remaining work.
